Philosophy is about giving you the thinking tools to seek truth for yourself. Philosophy is not going to lead you to truth. You are the only one that can lead yourself to truth.  For example, your car is not going to get you to school. You driving your car to school is going to get you to school.  Philosophy is not going to get you to truth. You using philosophy and seeking truth is going to lead you to truth.  Does philosophy have anything to do with truth? Can someone disagree with all philosophers but still be correct? The answer to both question is a yes.

Historically, the main distinguishing feature of philosophy versus ancient wisdom teachings is the clear presence of an epistemology in the work, or philosophy of knowledge. Since Plato, the standard account of knowledge has been that knowledge is justified true belief, sometimes called the JTB account. Each represents its own distinct condition for knowledge and can be studied independently. Most epistemology discuss theories of epistemic justification. Metaphysics, ontology, and logic discuss theories of truth. Belief is usually part of the discussion of philosophy of mind, which is often intertwined with philosophy of language. So yes, theories of truth primarily come out of philosophical discussions. You could call it one of the three pillars of philosophy. To get an introductory overview of some of the theories and issue which have been discussed so far, you might like to read Truth (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy).

One branch of philosophy is called Alethiology, and it is the study of the nature of truth. Other branches of philosophy do not claim to deal with truth, but in how to best explain topics such as epistemology - how we acquire knowledge, ethics- how do we determine good and evil, aesthetics- the nature of beauty, and several others which address all our experiences about our world. Philosophy cannot lead us to ultimate truth.
